columns.text: In this problem, we'll figure out the balloon payment for a $2,350,000 30-year mortgage with a 5.2 percent annual percentage rate and a monthly payment if we want to pay off the loan in only eight years.

Let's start with an explanation of what a balloon payment is.

A balloon payment is a large payment that occurs at the end of the loan's term. Balloon payments intend to pay off loans faster or compensate for smaller periodic loan installments by the borrower.

We'll look into the following details from the problem when determining the balloon payment.

| Particulars            |            |
|------------------------|------------|
| Loan amount            | $2,350,000    |
| Annual percentage rate | 5.2%       |
| Period                 | 30 (years) |

In determining the balloon payment amount, we will first calculate the monthly installment of the 30-year mortgage. We'll utilize the PMT function in Excel to calculate the monthly payment.

The PMT function calculates the periodic payment amount based on the present value, interest rate, and compounding period in a spreadsheet.

We can use the following syntax to use the PMT function in a spreadsheet:

$$\begin{aligned}
PMT&=(\text{rate},nper,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pv$, which represent the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year
Since we're calculating the monthly payment, we must get the monthly rate of the interest rate. If the annual percentage rate is 5.2%, we'll divide it over 12 to determine the monthly rate.

Next, we'll multiply the 30 years of the mortgage by 12 as the interest rates compound monthly.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Period} &=30\times12
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{360}
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the interest will compound 360 times.

We will consider the monthly rate and the period from the previous steps calculated and account for the mortgage amount as the present value in our computation in determining the monthly payment amount.

Let's use the PMT function in a spreadsheet to determine the monthly payment. For the formula to work correctly, the present value must be negative.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/93b0e5a8-aa60-428a-83ad-5c1732d1e1c7-1644153443748880.png)


As can be seen in our calculation, the monthly payment for the 30-year mortgage is $12,846.10.

Now that we have the periodic payment of $12,846.10 on the mortgage, we can compute the balloon payment using the present value of an annuity formula.

By multiplying the future constant payment with the interest rate and compounding period factor, the present value of an annuity calculation determines the present value of the future constant payment.

$$ \begin{aligned}
PVA &=C\times\dfrac{1-\dfrac{1}{\left(1+r\right)^t}}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PVA$, which means the present value of an annuity\
$C$, which represent the periodic payment\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

Since the periodic payment is made monthly, we will use the same monthly interest rate of  0.43%.

Next, we'll subtract the eight years from the 30-year mortgage duration to get the balloon payment on the eight-year. As a result, we will only discount our calculation by 22 years. As interest compounds monthly, we'll multiply the remaining 22 years by 12.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Period} &=22\times12
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{264}
\end{aligned}$$


Therefore, the period we'll consider in our calculation is 264.
To conclude, the balloon payment is $2,025,080.46 on a $2,350,000 30-year mortgage with monthly payments and an annual percentage rate of 5.2%.
